Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis of Chemically Stable Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons for High-Performance Organic Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: Organic semiconductors are of growing importance for solution-processed transistors, for lighting applications, and as materials used to generate solar energy due to the prospect for low-cost production of these materials. For all these applications, it is crucial that the organic semiconductor materials exhibit high performance and chemical stability. This project aims to develop a new class of organic semiconductor materials for use in high-performance electronic applications. Specifically, this project explores how molecular design will affect chemical stability, crystallization, and device performance. Understanding the structure-property relationship in these molecular systems will allow scientists to rationally design even better materials for use in real-world consumer electronic devices. In addition to providing research opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers from diverse backgrounds (utilizing the Graduate Students for Diversity in Science & Engineering at University of Massachusetts - Amherst that the PI created), the new scientific concepts created in this project are discussed in tutorials and workshops at international conferences, and also taught to high-school students from two nearby schools that serve a population of minority students in western Massachusetts.

Technical Description: This project explores the hypothesis that the addition of one or more aromatic pi sextets (benzenoid rings) in angular polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon semiconductors can improve the molecular packing in crystalline thin films, charge transport properties, and chemical stability due to increased resonance stabilization energies. The hypothesis is being verified through the characterization of crystalline thin films via x-ray analysis, transistor measurements, and theory/computational methods to explore transition states of pericyclic/cycloaddition reactions. The unique approach and use of a new class of aromatic semiconductors combined with theory and sophisticated scattering methods contribute to connecting fundamental principles of molecular design to charge transport at organic-organic and organic-substrate interfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic semiconductor materials are of growing importance for mass-produced solution-processed electronic circuits, RFID tags, low-resolution displays, lighting applications, and as sources of solar fuel due to the prospect for low-cost production of energy harvesting devices. For all these applications, the material's ability to efficiently generate charge carriers is essential, and it is well established that the size of the extended aromatic pi-electron system of the individual molecules and their mutual arrangement in the solid phase (molecular packing) determine the intrinsic rates of electrical transport. The main objective of this proposal was to understand the relationship between molecular design, crystal packing, self-assembly, and charge transport from a new class of crystalline organic semiconductors. We synthesized/functionalized polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and refer to them as "bis-oligoacenes" to provide handles over control of the electronic, molecular, solubility, and solid-state packing properties. Over the course of our funding period, we carried out characterization techniques to determine the fundamental electronic and photophysical properties of these materials.

One of our discoveries during this funding period includes the observation of a new thin film polymorph of bistetracene that is kinetically trapped under normal processing time scales. This phase can be converted to the bulk single crystal packing using a post-processing solvent annealing system that we monitored using in-situ GIXD measurements. Field-effect transistors fabricated from the solvent annealed films exhibited three orders of magnitude increase in hole mobility compared to the spin coated films. Our experiments highlight the importance of polymorph control in not just optimizing device performance, but can also be a powerful tool in better understanding the relationship between molecular packing and charge transport mechanism.

In another study, we determined that semiconductors such as pentacene and rubrene, when exposed to light and oxygen in solution, quickly degrade via a photo-oxidation reaction to produce transannular endoperoxides within a few minutes. The increased reactivity of the central ring of polyacenes towards Diels-Alder reactions with molecular oxygen in the presence of light has been attributed to a reduction in local aromaticity of the individual rings as a function of going towards the molecular center. Our results point out that the endoperoxide formation in bistetracene (BT) occurs not on the ring with least aromaticity, but rather on the ring with smallest activation strain energy, a feature supported by experimental HNMR analysis. Understanding the origin of the factors preventing oxidative degradation represents a major step towards the rational design of chemically stable organic semiconductors. Other studies carried out during this funding period include the observation that step edges on the surfaces of organic crystals can behave as "trapping" sites and will disrupt conductivity. We also formed several collaborations both from domestic and international researchers.

Our program has had broad impact in research areas striving to understand molecular structure to charge/energy transport, crystal packing, and self-assembly at interfaces. In addition to providing research opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students from diverse backgrounds, the concepts from this program was taught to the scientific community through invited lectures and workshops. To critically assess the status and future outlook of the field of organic electronics, we organized symposia at several MRS meetings and also ran a workshop/tutorial entitled,  "Organic Crystals 101." As a final note, we ensured the publication of 13 manuscripts during a three-year funding period in highly visible chemistry and materials science journals.


Last Modified: 11/26/2018
Modified by: Alejandro L Briseno
